column3: Love all these films. Just something about them.I do get a bit frustrated with all the ‚Äúoh I‚Äôm so laid back about cycling‚Äù thing. No di2 charger on a trip like this? I‚Äôd probably call BS on that.Anyway, really enjoyed this and thanks for showing the extreme Canada. Hope there is more to come in the future.
@raphafilms Sami's name is misspelled in the film blurb. Sauri not Saudi. Now, on with the show!
Please invite Juliana Buhring to your next Rapha Films long distance ride. She was in the ""Inspired to Ride"" film with the late great Mike Hall.
Really resonated with Gus' realization of the lack of empathy in riding
This is the second cycling video/trip I‚Äôve seen that the same person has knee issues that effect the group! Perhaps that person needs to reevaluate their distance goals?
Journeys about people not performance I freaking love it
Disc brakes ruined the look and the aerodynamic of the bicycles. üòû

On a long trip, use flat pedals to prevent from getting knee injuries. Clip in pedals are just to prevent slippage, they are not more efficient. Flat pedals are better in most situation, unless you are going racing.
Oh how I long for a trip like this... Nice one Dan... greetings from Namibia!
Love love love how you guys thoroughly and authentically connect w local people along the way.  Just so rad.
The film is awesome, inspiring, etc....  But, the soundtrack.  Love it!
Gus...   ""there is no right way to ride a bike""...   WRONG....  THERE IS NO WRONG WAY TO RIDE A BIKE...

Great film! Love that shit üëç

I‚Äôm from Sheshatshiu, across the River from North West River, I remember in the late 2000‚Äôs, my dad and I met a bicyclist on the highway between Churchill Falls and Goose, he biked all the way from New York, my dad invited him to our house for supper. I can‚Äôt remember his name, but he wanted to cook supper, so my mom said okay and then he took out his dirty, dusty bag of vegetables lol, after my mom seen the bag, she told him to use the our fresh vegetables instead. After supper, he asked my dad where he could get some ‚Äúgreen‚Äù, my dad took out his stash and they both got high that day lol, he had website documenting his travels but I can‚Äôt remember it
Love these videos. constantly got a grin on my face while watching.

Some harsh comments on here,Sami produced it and was more than just a rider.She didn't plan the knee pain and things happen.Hanging with this calibre of riders for anytime would be tough for most people.She has my respect.

At 1:13:55 his statement really meant a lot to me. When I stopped racing I felt like I lost my identity. Racing is WHAT I WAS. But it really wasn't. The bike was my escape and my solace growing up. And it still is / can be. I just needed to re-embrace that facet of it.

Crazy film, love it. Is not about get to the end is to enjoy all the thins that happens during the ride, people you meet, downs that happens,  shit food or a simple cup of coffee; are memories that will never leave you head. Looking foward to do something like that some day.

Boo and dislike for lack of transparency. Why don't you explain that you have a support vehicle and film crew? You have cereal boxes, large tents, cooking stuff, duffle bags. Either go ultralight with minimal "bikepacking" bags or get some panniers and earn it.

I don't know, something didn't feel right about this.  Beautiful country, much better adventurers out there and without a support vehicle.

Not a bad approach to riding this road. Most nights they are camping however I don't think their bikes are packed for that. Do they have support vehicles that are ahead or trailing that are setting up their site and dismantling? It'd be cool to see them bike-packing and carrying everything themself but I also suppose that isn't the intention of the ride. I'm not as critical as some other comments because I know at the end of the one of the primary goals of this is marketing.

I really enjoyed this one. The riding scenes were terrific, the camping and extreme bug-netting were surely honest to the real experience.The roadside stories were really interesting and came off genuine ‚Äì i especially loved the guy who built his own guitar.Regarding the crap talking about Sami's injury ... i can only imagine what riding with three seasoned pro riders would be like, but it surely wouldn't be easy. Good on her for taking on the challenge and making the most of it.
Thanks guys, really enjoyed the film.
Oh, and Sami and Gus, please go to film school for the summer and learn some basic principles of story telling. It needs more than a camera and some cash to actually make a "movie".
Not much of the stories behind them, but a lot of specialized and envie marketing... Some local bike builders would be more fitted to Rapha style ;)
57:58 Somebody knows the music?!
Love these movies! Certainly hope there are more to come!!
Cant handle that motherfuckers helmet. Other than that, fantastic.
rate it x

Outskirts team, this video was great and cycling's online community needs more work like this.  Great job everyone and thank you for this content.  Showing all sides of touring is important and with that comes all the small bits of drama shown here.  Can't wait for the next one.  Sami you are a legend and big inspiration to female cycling.  Cheers thanks to sponsors for making this happen
Nice one! Looking forward to Part 3.
Well that inspired me to go on a ride this evening.
Synthetic cycle travelers. I suspect they are completely unable to fix a puncture.
These are the types of videos I'm into watching and making lately. Capturing adventure and culture brought by a bicycle.
Having a Di2 bike to go bikepacking in the middle of nowhere seems like a great idea.

Nice piece of life. Thank you Sami for sharing your bitter ‚Äúside‚Äù story. So honest. It tells a lot of you. ... I am astonished by all the hateful comments. Everybody seems so obsessed with Perfection and competition (in riding, in filming, in storytelling). Thank you all for sharing your trip in those remote lands, meeting those nice people. And for sharing your current perspective on life. This make it more intimate and interesting for me. Happy new year to everyone.
really liked this, just like 1 and 2, bit more about, nature, culture and people which is good

Enjoyed it!  Thanks guys, this video series is excellent

It is a shit film as was the last one. Which is it? The ride or the people? At the moment you're telling nothing much of either story. There is no thread. I am not drawn to give a shit about anyone or anything happening which is a real shame as you all seem like great characters and the journey a magnificent one. When you rode your bikes and were directed by others in Thereabouts things were so much better.
Enjoyed the Outskirts video. Unfortunate for Sami, no one chooses to get injured.
Pretty good for a mellow watch. I enjoyed this one a bit more than the last one. If you like watching people ride bikes and do fun shit, check out Dklein 's youtube channel.
Awesome
I just didn't dig this as much as the Route 66 one. The map screens could've been a bit more detailed, I had literally no idea where they were riding until mid-way through and no sense of scale.

I dig it, fun to watch- gets you thinking about riding your own way- there is no one right way to ride a bike or make a film- these always inspire me to ride my bike, take more pictures, shoot more video - but that is just me. cheers, Steve aka The Talking Fly.

I really love this
If you guys need someone who can both ride and film in the next Outskirts, let me know!

As much as I like Gus, he came across as a bit of a dick! He made the point that Sami was not a professional!!! Surely the point of these films are about exploring? Nobody cares if it takes 10 or 30 days. It's about experiencing the people and the land. These series would be better with cyclist who really struggle with a trip like that to make it real!! Kit them up in Rapha and not flowery shirts. Show the rest of us something real to aspire to and how your kit can help them!
